Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 02:56PM san4850 wrote: I had a lumpectomy first, then an SNB later, and I didn't have a drain.  My surgeon told me before the SNB surgery that if the sentinel node is clear, then he wouldn't have to take out anymore nodes, and I wouldn't need a drain.  I never had any problems.
Posts.Title: Drain with SNB? MinAZ emath

Posts.Content: san4850 wrote: Does it matter what time of the month you should get an MRI?  My dr. is thinking about having me get them, but she says I need to schedule it no more than 3 days after my period because timing is important.  I didn't know it was.  Since I've been on tamoxifen for over 15 months now, my periods have been so irregular.  Before going on tamox, I knew when I could expect to get my period, and it came like clockwork.  Now I can go anywhere from 1 to 2 months before I'll get my next period.  I'm still premenopausal.  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Question about what when to get an MRI.. san4850 rockwell_girl

Posts.Content: May 9, 2007 02:12PM san4850 wrote: I agree with peachy. How about Mayo Clinic? I know there's one in Jacksonville. I'm currently getting my treatment at the Mayo Clinic in Scottsdale, AZ. They're a research/teaching hospital, and when it comes to the newest techniques and procedures, they're always on the cutting edge. They are also a designated Comprehensive Cancer Center, and in my opinion, you won't find a BETTER place to get cancer care than at Mayo.
Posts.Title: Jacksonville, Florida elysabeth1971 san4850

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2008 05:06PM san4850 wrote: If your SNB is found to be negative, then you'll be just fine.  The fact that it's a grade 1 means that the cells look like normal cells even though they are malignant, and that means more slower growing.  In general, b/c is a very slow growing cancer.  When yours was diagnosed, you probably had it for at least 8 years and didn't even know it, and now it got to a size where it was able to be detected on either a mammogram or ultrasound.  That's how slow growing b/c is.
Posts.Title: Can grade 1 IDC spread if it's less than 2cm? Lynette pod1257

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2008 11:57AM san4850 wrote: If they look like pimples or something along that line, they could be nothing more than that, or a boil, but I say if she's had it for several months and it won't go away, she might want to have it checked out just to ease her mind. I had a very large pimple just all of a sudden appear overnight right under my armpit that I felt in the shower.  It hurt, and I put some benzoyl peroxide on it, and it did shrink, but it took a while for it to go away.  Just a week before this pimple appeared, I saw my dr for a regular checkup and she gave me a clinical breast exam and that pimple wasn't there at that time.  2 months later I saw a nurse at the breast clinic and told her about this (by that time the pimple was all but gone) and the nurse said it could have been either acne or a boil, because she could see where it had been.
Posts.Title: Pimples? sandie57 san4850

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 01:45PM san4850 wrote: My oncotype score was also 16.  I had 0/6 negative nodes (including 2 sentinel nodes), and I had a 2.5 cm tumor.  I didn't do chemo.  Just 30 rads (24 + 6 boosts) and now on tamox.  The first onc told me I needed chemo, but that's because he didn't even offer me the oncotype test.  I went for a second opinion, and this second onc insisted on the oncotype test because he thought chemo was overkill when he saw my pathology report.
Posts.Title: Oncotype DX 16 gj60 san4850

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2007 09:20AM san4850 wrote: I *THINK* fine needle aspiration draws out cells or fluid from a lump. If the lump is a cyst, it will naturally collapse down after that, and it uses a thinner needle. A biopsy (as in core needle) uses a thicker needle and draws actual tissue from the lump, not only cells. Neither procedure hurts. The surgeon or radiologist numbs the area, but the initial injection of local anesthetic feels like an insect bite at most. After that, you don't feel a thing. The procedure is done right in the office, you're awake the whole time, and you don't have to fast. Everytime the radiologist did something, she asked me if it hurt. I told her no, she said "good, that's the answer I want to hear."
Posts.Title: FNA/biopsy, whats the difference? tammi86 san4850

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2008 06:47PM san4850 wrote: Surprisingly I didn't suffer that much fatigue.  I worked the entire time.  Went thru 6 weeks of rads, left work by 3:30 pm, and my drive was 45 minutes from work to the treatment center.  Some days I even did a workout dvd when I got home.  Made sure I was in bed by no later than 8:30, maybe 8:45 each night, so I could get my 8 hours of sleep.  It was inconvenient, but do-able.  The only thing I suffered from was the burns.
Posts.Title: Anyone not fatigued by Rads? Breeze shepherdess

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2009 10:13PM san4850 wrote: I don't know how long my results took.  My onc. decided to give this test to me, even though I didn't know what it was for and I'd never heard about it.  I figured he was the doctor and he knew what he was doing.  After I took the test, I started radiation and never thought about it.  When I finished radiation, he put me on tamox, said the test indicated I was a good metabolizer.

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 04:07PM san4850 wrote: I had SNB on my left side, and I'm right handed too.  I had the SNB on a Friday (had the lumpectomy a few weeks prior).  My friend drove me and I stayed the night at her house.  The next day I was able to drive, but I needed 1 Percocet.  By Monday morning I was back at work.  My boss was surprised to see me, and my surgeon even gave me a note for my employer explaining my absence, but I didn't need it.  I was fine.
